Let the bird of loudest lay
On the sole Arabian tree
Herald sad and trumpet be
To whose sound chaste wings obey.
But thou shrieking harbinger
Foul precurrer of the fiend
Augur of the fever's end
To this troop come thou not near.
From this session interdict
Every fowl of tyrant wing
Save the eagle
Keep the obsequy so strict.
Let the priest in surplice white
That defunctive music can
Be the death-divining swan
Lest the requiem lack his right.
And thou treble-dated crow
That thy sable gender mak'st
With the breath thou giv'st and tak'st
'Mongst our mourners shalt thou go.
Here the anthem doth commence:
Love and constancy is dead;
Phoenix and the Turtle fled
In a mutual flame from hence.
So they lov'd
Had the essence but in one;
Two distincts
Number there in love was slain.
Hearts remote
Distance and no space was seen
'Twixt this Turtle and his queen:
But in them it were a wonder.
So between them love did shine
That the Turtle saw his right
Flaming in the Phoenix' sight:
Either was the other's mine.
Property was thus appalled
That the self was not the same;
Single nature's double name
Neither two nor one was called.
Reason
Saw division grow together
To themselves yet either neither
Simple were so well compounded;
That it cried
Seemeth this concordant one!
Love has reason
If what parts can so remain."
Whereupon it made this threne
To the Phoenix and the Dove
Co-supremes and stars of love
As chorus to their tragic scene:

Death is now the Phoenix' nest
And the Turtle's loyal breast
To eternity doth rest
Leaving no posterity:
'Twas not their infirmity
It was married chastity.
Truth may seem but cannot be;
Beauty brag but 'tis not she;
Truth and beauty buried be.
To this urn let those repair
That are either true or fair;
For these dead birds sigh a prayer.
Sir Charles into my chamber coming in

I praysaid hewhen Queen Mab you do see
Present my service to her Majesty:
And tell her I have heard Fame's loud report

When I Queen Mab within my fancy viewed
My thoughts bowed low
Kissing her garment thin which fancy made
I knelt upon a thought
And then
His humble service which in mirth was sent;
Thus by imagination I have been

Mirrour of grace and Majestie divine
Great Lady of the greatest Isle
Like Phoebus lampe throughout the world doth shine
Shed thy faire beames into my feeble eyne
And raise my thoughts too humble and too vile
To thinke of that true glorious type of thine
The argument of mine afflicted stile:
The which to heare
i
A Gentle Knight was pricking on the plaine
Y cladd in mightie armes and silver shielde
Wherein old dints of deepe wounds did remaine
The cruell markes of many a bloudy fielde;
Yet armes till that time did he never wield:
His angry steede did chide his foming bitt
As much disdayning to the curbe to yield:
Full jolly knight he seemd
As one for knightly giusts and fierce encounters fitt.
ii
But on his brest a bloudie Crosse he bore
The deare remembrance of his dying Lord
For whose sweete sake that glorious badge he wore
And dead as living ever him ador'd:
Upon his shield the like was also scor'd
For soveraine hope
column2: which in his helpe he had:

column1: Right faithfull true he was in deede and word
But of his cheere did seeme too solemne sad;
Yet nothing did he dread
iii
Upon a great adventure he was bond
That greatest Gloriana to him gave
That greatest Glorious Queene of Faerie lond
To winne him worship
Which of all earthly things he most did crave;
And ever as he rode
To prove his puissance in battell brave
Upon his foe
column2: and his new force to learne;

column1: Upon his foe
iv
A lovely Ladie rode him faire beside
Upon a lowly Asse more white then snow
Yet she much whiter
Under a vele
And over all a blacke stole she did throw
As one that inly mournd: so was she sad
And heavie sat upon her palfrey slow;
Seemed in heart some hidden care she had
And by her in a line a milke white lambe she lad.
v
So pure an innocent
She was in life and every vertuous lore
And by descent from Royall lynage came
Of ancient Kings and Queenes
Their scepters stretcht from East to Westerne shore
And all the world in their subjection held;
Till that infernall feend with foule uprore
Forwasted all their land
Whom to avenge
column2: she had this Knight from far compeld.

column1: vi
Behind her farre away a Dwarfe did lag
That lasie seemd in being ever last
Or wearied with bearing of her bag
Of needments at his backe. Thus as they past
The day with cloudes was suddeine overcast
And angry Jove an hideous storme of raine
Did poure into his Lemans lap so fast
That every wight to shrowd it did constrain
And this faire couple eke to shroud themselves were fain.
vii
Enforst to seeke some covert nigh at hand
A shadie grove not far away they spide
That promist ayde the tempest to withstand:
Whose loftie trees yclad with sommers pride
Did spred so broad
Not perceable with power of any starre:
And all within were pathes and alleies wide
With footing worne
Faire harbour that them seemes; so in they entred arre.
viii
And foorth they passe
Joying to heare the birdes sweete harmony
Which therein shrouded from the tempest dred
Seemd in their song to scorne the cruell sky.
Much can they prayse the trees so straight and hy
The sayling Pine
The vine-prop Elme
The builder Oake
The Aspine good for staves
ix
The Laurell
And Poets sage
The Willow worne of forlorne Paramours
The Eugh obedient to the benders will
The Birch for shaftes
The Mirrhe sweete bleeding in the bitter wound
The warlike Beech
The fruitfull Olive
The carver Holme
x
Led with delight
Untill the blustring storme is overblowne;
When weening to returne
They cannot find that path
But wander too and fro in wayes unknowne
Furthest from end then
That makes them doubt

xi
At last resolving forward still to fare
Till that some end they finde or in or out
That path they take
And like to lead the labyrinth about;
Which when by tract they hunted had throughout
At length it brought them to a hollow cave
Amid the thickest woods. The Champion stout
Eftsoones dismounted from his courser brave
And to the Dwarfe a while his needlesse spere he gave.
xii
Be well aware
Least suddaine mischiefe ye too rash provoke:
The danger hid
Breeds dreadfull doubts: Oft fire is without smoke

Sir knight with-hold

xiv
But full of fire and greedy hardiment
The youthfull knight could not for ought be staide
But forth unto the darksome hole he went
And looked in: his glistring armor made
A litle glooming light
By which he saw the ugly monster plaine
Halfe like a serpent horribly displaide
But th'other halfe did womans shape retaine
Most lothsom
xv
And as she lay upon the durtie ground
Her huge long taile her den all overspred
Yet was in knots and many boughtes upwound
Pointed with mortall sting. Of her there bred
A thousand yong ones
Sucking upon her poisonous dugs
Of sundry shapes
Soone as that uncouth light upon them shone
Into her mouth they crept
xvi
Their dam upstart
And rushed forth
About her cursed head
Were stretcht now forth at length without entraile.
She lookt about
Armed to point
For light she hated as the deadly bale
Ay wont in desert darknesse to remaine
Where plaine none might her see
xvii
Which when the valiant Elfe perceiv'd
As Lyon fierce upon the flying pray
And with his trenchand blade her boldly kept
From turning backe
Therewith enrag'd she loudly gan to bray
And turning fierce
Threatning her angry sting
Who nought aghast
The stroke down from her head unto her shoulder glaunst.
xviii
Much daunted with that dint
Yet kindling rage
And all attonce her beastly body raizd
With doubled forces high above the ground:
Tho wrapping up her wrethed sterne arownd
Lept fierce upon his shield
All suddenly about his body wound
That hand or foot to stirre he strove in vaine:
God helpe the man so wrapt in Errours endlesse traine.
xix

Therewith she spewd out of her filthy maw
A floud of poyson horrible and blacke

column1: Her vomit full of bookes and papers was
With loathly frogs and toades
And creeping sought way in the weedy gras:
Her filthy parbreake all the place defiled has.
xxi
As when old father Nilus gins to swell
With timely pride above the Aegyptian vale
His fattie waves do fertile slime outwell
And overflow each plaine and lowly dale:
But when his later spring gins to avale
Huge heapes of mudd he leaves
Ten thousand kindes of creatures
And partly female of his fruitfull seed;
Such ugly monstrous shapes elsewhere may no man reed.
xxii
The same so sore annoyed has the knight
That welnigh choked with the deadly stinke
His forces faile
Whose corage when the feend perceiv'd to shrinke
She poured forth out of her hellish sinke
Her fruitfull cursed spawne of serpents small
Deformed monsters
Which swarming all about his legs did crall

column2: but could not hurt at all.

column1: xxiii
As gentle Shepheard in sweete even-tide
When ruddy Phoebus gins to welke in west
High on an hill
Markes which do byte their hasty supper best;
A cloud of combrous gnattes do him molest
All striving to infixe their feeble stings
That from their noyance he no where can rest
But with his clownish hands their tender wings
He brusheth oft
column2: and oft doth mar their murmurings.

column1: xxiv
Thus ill bestedd
Then of the certaine perill he stood in
Halfe furious unto his foe he came
Resolv'd in minde all suddenly to win
Or soone to lose
And strooke at her with more then manly force
That from her body full of filthie sin
He raft her hatefull head without remorse;
A streame of cole black bloud forth gushed from her corse.
xxv
Her scattred brood
They saw so rudely falling to the ground
Groning full deadly
Gathred themselves about her body round
Weening their wonted entrance to have found
At her wide mouth: but being there withstood
They flocked all about her bleeding wound
And sucked up their dying mothers blood
Making her death their life
column2: and eke her hurt their good.

column1: xxvi
That detestable sight him much amazde
To see th'unkindly Impes of heaven accurst
Devoure their dam; on whom while so he gazd
Having all satisfide their bloudy thurst
Their bellies swolne he saw with fulnesse burst
And bowels gushing forth: well worthy end
Of such as drunke her life
Now needeth him no lenger labour spend
His foes have slaine themselves
xxvii
His Ladie seeing all
Approcht in hast to greet his victorie
And said
Who see your vanquisht foes before you lye:
Well worthy be you of that Armorie
Wherein ye have great glory wonne this day
And proov'd your strength on a strong enimie
Your first adventure: many such I pray
And henceforth ever wish
xxviii
Then mounted he upon his Steede againe
And with the Lady backward sought to wend;
That path he kept
Ne ever would to any by-way bend
But still did follow one unto the end
The which at last out of the wood them brought.
So forward on his way (with God to frend)
He passed forth
Long way he travelled
xxix
At length they chaunst to meet upon the way
An aged Sire
His feete all bare
And by his belt his booke he hanging had;
Sober he seemde
And to the ground his eyes were lowly bent
Simple in shew
And all the way he prayed
And often knockt his brest
xxx
He faire the knight saluted
Who faire him quited
And after asked him
Of straunge adventures
Ah my deare Sonne (quoth he) how should
Silly old man
Bidding his beades all day for his trespas
Tydings of warre and worldly trouble tell?
With holy father sits not with such things to mell.
xxxi
But if of daunger which hereby doth dwell
And homebred evill ye desire to heare
Of a straunge man I can you tidings tell
That wasteth all this countrey farre and neare.
Of such (said he) I chiefly do inquere
And shall you well reward to shew the place
In which that wicked wight his dayes doth weare:
For to all knighthood it is foule disgrace
That such a cursed creature lives so long a space.
xxxii
Far hence (quoth he) in wastfull wildernesse
His dwelling is
May ever passe
Now (sayd the Lady) draweth toward night
And well I wote
Ye all forwearied be: for what so strong
But wanting rest will also want of might?
The Sunne that measures heaven all day long
At night doth baite his steedes the Ocean waves emong.
xxxiii
Then with the Sunne take Sir
And with new day new worke at once begin:
Untroubled night they say gives counsell best.
Right well Sir knight ye have advised bin
(Quoth then that aged man;) the way to win
Is wisely to advise: now day is spent;
Therefore with me ye may take up your In
For this same night. The knight was well content:
So with that godly father to his home they went.
xxxiv
A little lowly Hermitage it was
Downe in a dale
Far from resort of people
In travell to and froe: a little wyde
There was an holy Chappell edifyde
Wherein the Hermite dewly wont to say
His holy things each morne and eventyde:
Thereby a Christall streame did gently play
Which from a sacred fountaine welled forth alway.
xxxv
Arrived there
Ne looke for entertainement

Praisd be Dianas fair and harmless light;
Praisd be the dews wherewith she moists the ground;
Praisd be her beams
Praisd be her power by which all powers abound.
Praisd be her nymphs with whom she decks the woods
Praisd be her knights in whom true honour lives;
Praisd be that force by which she moves the floods;
Let that Diana shine which all these gives.
In heaven queen she is among the spheres;
In aye she mistress-like makes all things pure;
Eternity in her oft change she bears;
She beauty is; by her the fair endure.
Time wears her not: she doth his chariot guide;
Mortality below her orb is placd;
